introduction.p: In this chapter, we have been looking at bases for \real^p, sets of vectors that are linearly independent and span \real^p. Frequently, however, we focus on only a subset of \real^p. In particular, if we are given an m\times n matrix A, we have been interested in both the span of the columns of A and the solution space to the homogeneous equation A\xvec = \zerovec. In this section, we will expand the concept of basis to describe sets like these.

Let's consider the following matrix A and its reduced row echelon form.
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 2 \amp -1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ -2 \amp 2 \amp -4 \amp -2 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -2 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .

statement.p: Are the columns of A linearly independent? Is the span of the columns \real^3?

solution.p: The columns of A are not linearly independent since there is not a pivot position in every column. Also, the span of the columns is not \real^3 because there is not a pivot position in every row.

statement.p: Give a parametric description of the solution space to the homogeneous equation A\xvec = \zerovec.
Explain how this parametric description produces two vectors \wvec_1 and \wvec_2 whose span is the solution space to the equation A\xvec = \zerovec.

solution.p: We see that every vector in the solution space is a linear combination of the vectors \wvec_1=\fourvec{0}{2}{1}{0} and \wvec_2 = \fourvec{2}{-1}{0}{1}.

statement.p: What can you say about the linear independence of the set of vectors \wvec_1 and \wvec_2?

solution.p: This pair of vectors is linearly independent because one is not a scalar multiple of the other.

statement.p: Let's denote the columns of A as \vvec_1, \vvec_2, \vvec_3, and \vvec_4. Explain why \vvec_3 and \vvec_4 can be written as linear combinations of \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.

solution.p: From the reduced row echelon form of A, we see that \vvec_3 = -2\vvec_2 and \vvec_4=2\vvec_1+\vvec_2.

statement.p: Explain why \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 are linearly independent and \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2} = \laspan{\vvec_1, \vvec_2, \vvec_3, \vvec_4}.

solution.p: We see that \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 are linearly independent from the reduced row echelon form of A. Moreover, we know that \vvec_3 and \vvec_4 can be written as linear combinations of \vvec_1 and \vvec_2. Therefore, any linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, \vvec_3, and \vvec_4 can be written as a linear combination of \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 alone.

subsection.title: Subspaces
subsection.p: Our goal is to develop a common framework for describing subsets like the span of the columns of a matrix and the solution space to a homogeneous equation. That leads us to the following definition.

statement.p: A subspace of \real^p is a subset of \real^p that is the span of a set of vectors.

subsection.p: Since we have explored the concept of span in some detail, this definition just gives us a new word to describe something familiar. Let's look at some examples.

example.title: Subspaces of \real^3
example.p:
In and the following discussion, we looked at subspaces in \real^3 without explicitly using that language. Let's recall some of those examples.
Suppose we have a single nonzero vector \vvec. The span of \vvec is a subspace, which we'll write as S = \laspan{\vvec}. As we have seen, the span of a single vector consists of all scalar multiples of that vector, and these form a line passing through the origin.
A line formed by all scalar multiples of a three dimensional vector.
A three dimensional diagram showing the three coordinate axes, a vector \vvec, and the line formed by all scalar multiples of \vvec.
If instead we have two linearly independent vectors \vvec_1 and \vvec_2, the subspace S=\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2} is a plane passing through the origin.
A three dimensional diagram with two vectors and the plane formed by all their linear combinations.
A three dimensional diagram with two vectors \vvec_1 and \vvec_2. The set of all their linear combinations is shown as a plane passing through the origin.
Consider the three vectors \evec_1, \evec_2, and \evec_3. Since we know that every 3-dimensional vector can be written as a linear combination, we have S = \laspan{\evec_1, \evec_2, \evec_3} = \real^3.
One more subspace worth mentioning is S=\laspan{\zerovec}. Since any linear combination of the zero vector is itself the zero vector, this subspace consists of a single vector, \zerovec.
In fact, any subspace of \real^3 is one of these types: the origin, a line, a plane, or all of \real^3.

\wvec_1=\threevec210,~~~ \wvec_2=\threevec{-1}1{-1},~~~ \wvec_3=\threevec03{-2}

\begin{bmatrix} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \vvec_3 \amp \vvec_4 \end{bmatrix} \sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}.
Give a description of the subspace S=\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3,\vvec_4} of \real^3.

li.p:
If we choose all the weights c_1=c_2=\ldots=c_n = 0, then the linear combination
c_1\vvec_1 + c_2\vvec_2 + \cdots + c_n\vvec_n = \zerovec.
This means that \zerovec is the subspace S=\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n}.

The line on the left cannot be a subspace of \real^2 since it does not contain the zero vector. The line on the right is a subspace because it can be represented as the span of any nonzero vector on the line.
The matrix whose columns are the given vectors has a pivot in every row. Therefore, the span of these vectors is \real^3 and so S=\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} = \real^3.
We see that \wvec_3 = \wvec_1 + 2\wvec_2.

Any linear combination
c_1\wvec_1 + c_2\wvec_2 + c_2\wvec_3 = (c_1 + c_2)\wvec_1 + (c_2+2c_2)\wvec_2.
The subspace S=\laspan{\wvec_1,\wvec_2,\wvec_3} = \laspan{\wvec_1,\wvec_2} is a plane in \real^3.

Since we can write \vvec_2 = 2\vvec_1 and \vvec_4 = -2\vvec_1 + \vvec_2, then
S = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3,\vvec_4} = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_3},
which is a plane in \real^3.

subsection.p: As the activity shows, it is possible to represent some subspaces as the span of more than one set of vectors. We are particularly interested in representing a subspace as the span of a linearly independent set of vectors.

statement.p: A basis for a subspace S of \real^p is a set of vectors in S that are linearly independent and whose span is S. We say that the dimension of the subspace S, denoted \dim S, is the number of vectors in any basis.

example.title: A subspace of \real^4
example.p:
Suppose we have the 4-dimensional vectors \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3 that define the subspace S = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} of \real^4. Suppose also that
\begin{bmatrix} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \vvec_3 \end{bmatrix} \sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}.
From the reduced row echelon form of the matrix, we see that \vvec_2 = -\vvec. Therefore, any linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3 can be rewritten
c_1\vvec_1 + c_2\vvec_2 + c_3 \vvec_3 = (c_1-c_2)\vvec_1 + c_2\vvec_3
as a linear combination of \vvec_1 and \vvec_3. This tells us that
S = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_3}.

Furthermore, the reduced row echelon form of the matrix shows that \vvec_1 and \vvec_3 are linearly independent. Therefore, \{\vvec_1,\vvec_3\} is a basis for S, which means that S is a two-dimensional subspace of \real^4.

subsection.p:
Subspaces of \real^3 are either
0-dimensional, consisting of the single vector \zerovec,
a 1-dimensional line,
a 2-dimensional plane, or
the 3-dimensional subspace \real^3.
There is no 4-dimensional subspace of \real^3 because there is no linearly independent set of four vectors in \real^3.

There are two important subspaces associated to any matrix, each of which springs from one of our
two fundamental questions,
as we will now see.

subsection.title: The column space of A
subsection.p: The first subspace associated to a matrix that we'll consider is its column space.

statement.p: If A is an m\times n matrix, we call the span of its columns the column space of A and denote it as \col(A).

subsection.p: Notice that the columns of A are vectors in \real^m, which means that any linear combination of the columns is also in \real^m. Since the column space is described as the span of a set of vectors, we see that \col(A) is a subspace of \real^m.

statement.p:
We will explore some column spaces in this activity.
Consider the matrix A= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \vvec_3 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 3 \amp -1 \\ -2 \amp 0 \amp -4 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right].
Since \col(A) is the span of the columns, we have
\col(A) = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}.
Explain why \vvec_3 can be written as a linear combination of \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 and why \col(A)=\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}.
Explain why the vectors \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 form a basis for \col(A) and why \col(A) is a 2-dimensional subspace of \real^3 and therefore a plane.
Now consider the matrix B and its reduced row echelon form:
B = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} -2 \amp -4 \amp 0 \amp 6 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp -3 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp -3 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right].
Explain why \col(B) is a 1-dimensional subspace of \real^2 and is therefore a line.
For a general matrix A, what is the relationship between the dimension \dim~\col(A) and the number of pivot positions in A?
How does the location of the pivot positions indicate a basis for \col(A)?
If A is an invertible 9\times9 matrix, what can you say about the column space \col(A)?
Suppose that A is an 8\times 10 matrix and that \col(A) = \real^8. If \bvec is an 8-dimensional vector, what can you say about the equation A\xvec = \bvec?

li.p:
We have A=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 3 \amp -1 \\ -2 \amp 0 \amp -4 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{,}
which shows that the vectors are not linearly independent and, in fact, that \vvec_3 = 2\vvec_1 - \vvec_2. As we've seen several times, this means that any linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3 can be written as a linear combination of \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 alone and hence that \col(A)=\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}.
The reduced row echelon form of A shows that \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 are linearly independent. We also know that the span of these two vectors is \col(A). Therefore, they form a basis for \col(A).

Denoting the columns of B as \vvec_i, the reduced row echelon form shows that \vvec_2=2\vvec_1, \vvec_3=0\vvec_1, and \vvec_4 = -3\vvec_1. Therefore, any linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, \vvec_3, and \vvec_4 can be written as a linear combination of \vvec_1 alone. This means that \vvec_1 forms a basis for \col(A), which is then the line consisting of all scalar multiples of \vvec_1. p
The number of vectors in a basis of \col(A) equals the number of pivot positions. Therefore, \dim~\col(A) equals the number of pivot positions in A.
As the examples in this activity illustrate, the columns of A that contain pivot positions form a basis for \col(A).
If A is invertible, then it has a pivot position in every row, which means that the span of the columns is \real^9. Therefore, \col(A) = \real^9.
Since \col(A)=\real^8, we know that every 8-dimensional vector \bvec is in \col(A). This means that \bvec is in the span of the columns of A so the equation A\xvec = \bvec must be consistent.

example.p:
Consider the matrix A and its reduced row echelon form:
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrrr} 2 \amp 0 \amp -4 \amp -6 \amp 0 \\ -4 \amp -1 \amp 7 \amp 11 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \amp -3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right],
and denote the columns of A as \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_5.

It is certainly true that \col(A) = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_5} by the definition of the column space. However, the reduced row echelon form of the matrix shows us that the vectors are not linearly independent so \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_5 do not form a basis for \col(A).

From the reduced row echelon form, however, we can see that
\begin{aligned} \vvec_3 \amp {}={} -2\vvec_1 + \vvec_2 \\ \vvec_4 \amp {}={} -3\vvec_1 + \vvec_2 \\ \vvec_5 \amp {}={} -2\vvec_2 \\ \end{aligned} . This means that any linear combination of \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_5 can be written as a linear combination of just \vvec_1 and \vvec_2. Therefore, we see that \col(A) = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}.

Moreover, the reduced row echelon form shows that \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 are linearly independent, which implies that they form a basis for \col(A). This means that \col(A) is a 2-dimensional subspace of \real^3, which is a plane in \real^3, having basis
\threevec{2}{-4}{0}, \qquad \threevec{0}{-1}{1} .

subsection.p: In general, a column without a pivot position can be written as a linear combination of the columns that have pivot positions. This means that a basis for \col(A) will always be given by the columns of A having pivot positions. This leads us to the following definition and proposition.

statement.p: The rank of a matrix A is the number of pivot positions in A and is denoted by \rank(A).
If A is an m\times n matrix, then \col(A) is a subspace of \real^m whose dimension equals \rank(A). The columns of A that contain pivot positions form a basis for \col(A).

subsection.p: For example, the rank of the matrix A in is two because there are two pivot positions. A basis for \col(A) is given by the first two columns of A since those columns have pivot positions.

As a note of caution, we determine the pivot positions by looking at the reduced row echelon form of A. However, we form a basis of \col(A) from the columns of A rather than the columns of the reduced row echelon matrix.

subsection.title: The null space of A
subsection.p: The second subspace associated to a matrix is its null space.

statement.p: If A is an m\times n matrix, we call the subset of vectors \xvec in \real^n satisfying A\xvec = \zerovec the null space of A and denote it by \nul(A).

subsection.p: Remember that a subspace is a subset that can be represented as the span of a set of vectors. The column space of A, which is simply the span of the columns of A, fits this definition. It may not be immediately clear how the null space of A, which is the solution space of the equation A\xvec = \zerovec, does, but we will see that \nul(A) is a subspace of \real^n.

li.p:
We have A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 3 \amp -1 \amp 2 \\ -2 \amp 0 \amp -4 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}\sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0\\ \end{bmatrix},
which leads to the parametric description of the solution space to the homogeneous equation: \xvec=x_3\fourvec{-2}{1}{1}0 + x_4\fourvec{1}{-1}01.
The parametric description shows that every solution to the equation A\xvec=\zerovec is a linear combination of \wvec_1=\fourvec{-2}110 and \wvec_2=\fourvec1{-1}01.
The vectors \wvec_1 and \wvec_2 are linearly independent so they form a basis for \nul(A). Therefore, \nul(A) is 2-dimensional.
The vectors in \nul(A) are 4-dimensional so \nul(A) is a subspace of \real^4.

A parametric description of the null space is \xvec=x_2\fourvec{-2}{1}{0}{0} + x_3\fourvec0010 + x_4\fourvec{3}{0}{-2}{1}. We can check that the vectors
\fourvec{-2}100,~~~\fourvec0010,~~~\fourvec30{-2}1
are linearly independent so they form a basis for \nul(A). This means that \nul(A) is 3-dimensional.

The number of vectors in a basis of the null space equals the number of free variables that appear in the equation A\xvec=\zerovec, which is the number of columns that do not have pivot positions. This says that \dim~\nul(A) equals the number of columns of A minus the number of pivot positions.
If the columns are linearly independent, then the homogeneous equation A\xvec=\zerovec has only the zero solution \xvec=\zerovec. Therefore, \nul(A) = \{\zerovec\}.

example.p:
Consider the matrix A along with its reduced row echelon form:
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrrr} 2 \amp 0 \amp -4 \amp -6 \amp 0 \\ -4 \amp -1 \amp 7 \amp 11 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \amp -3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}

This expression says that any vector \xvec satisfying A\xvec= \zerovec is a linear combination of the vectors
\vvec_1 = \fivevec{2}{-1}{1}{0}{0},~~~ \vvec_2 = \fivevec{3}{-1}{0}{1}{0},~~~ \vvec_3 = \fivevec{0}{2}{0}{0}{1}.
It is straightforward to check that these vectors are linearly independent, which means that \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3 form a basis for \nul(A), a 3-dimensional subspace of \real^5.

subsection.p: As illustrated in this example, the dimension of \nul(A) is equal to the number of free variables in the equation A\xvec=\zerovec, which equals the number of columns of A without pivot positions or the number of columns of A minus the number of pivot positions.

statement.p:
If A is an m\times n matrix, then \nul(A) is a subspace of \real^n whose dimension is
\dim~\nul(A) = n - \rank(A).

If A is an m\times n matrix, then
\dim~\col(A) + \dim~\nul(A) = n.

subsection.title: Summary
subsection.p:
Once again, we find ourselves revisiting
our two fundamental questions
concerning the existence and uniqueness of solutions to linear systems. The column space \col(A) contains all the vectors \bvec for which the equation A\xvec = \bvec is consistent. The null space \nul(A) is the solution space to the equation A\xvec = \zerovec, which reflects on the uniqueness of solutions to this and other equations.

li.p: A subspace S of \real^p is a subset of \real^p that can be represented as the span of a set of vectors. A basis of S is a linearly independent set of vectors whose span is S.
If A is an m\times n matrix, the column space \col(A) is the span of the columns of A and forms a subspace of \real^m.
A basis for \col(A) is found from the columns of A that have pivot positions. The dimension is therefore \dim~\col(A) = \rank(A).
The null space \nul(A) is the solution space to the homogeneous equation A\xvec = \zerovec and is a subspace of \real^n.
A basis for \nul(A) is found through a parametric description of the solution space of A\xvec = \zerovec, and we have that \dim~\nul(A) = n - \rank(A).
